meta.title: Overview of immunology and primary immunodeficiencies

content:
Introduction

The immune system is complex, with overlapping pathways.  This article provides an overview of the immune system by conceptualizing it based on 2 major branches:

  • Innate immunity refers to a rapid generalized response that remains constant with each exposure.  It occurs at the site of infection.
  • Adaptive immunity refers to a slower, memory-based response to specific pathogens that improves over time.  It begins when antigen-presenting cells (APCs [eg, dendritic cells]) move from the site of infection to the nearest lymphoid tissue (eg, lymph node).  The adaptive immune branch is subdivided into 2 categories:
    • Cell-mediated immunity (T cells) is characterized by direct killing of intracellularly infected or abnormal cells (cytotoxic T-cell response) and broad assistance of other immune cells (helper T-cell response).
    • Antibody-mediated (humoral) immunity (B cells, antibodies) is characterized by neutralization, tagging, and opsonization of extracellular pathogens.

Most infections trigger both innate and adaptive responses to varying degrees.  The article ends with a brief overview of primary immunodeficiencies, some of which are discussed in more detail in separate articles.

Innate immunity

Components

Innate immune components consist of the following (

figure 1
):

  • Natural barriers:  Skin and mucosa are the first lines of defense.  Breach of these barriers (eg, splinter) creates a portal of entry for pathogens such as normally benign flora.  Natural respiratory defenses include the ciliary escalator and secretions with antimicrobial proteins (eg, defensins, mucins).  Innate gastrointestinal defenses include peptic acid and digestive enzymes.
  • Contact activation system:  Exposed subendothelial basement membrane (eg, tissue factor) activates local coagulation; this forms a fibrin-rich clot that blocks pathogens from entering the bloodstream.  Concurrently, the kallikrein-kinin system is activated, inducing local vasodilation (eg, bradykinin) and vascular permeability, which allows innate immune cells to infiltrate the infected tissue.
  • Innate immune cells:  Innate immune cells consist of granulocytes (neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils), natural killer (NK) cells, and phagocytes (macrophages, dendritic cells).  The specific function of these cells is discussed below.
  • Inflammasome:  The inflammasome is a large multiprotein complex that induces pyroptosis (inflammatory cell death) and pro-inflammatory cytokines (eg, IL-1êžµ, IL-18) to recruit more innate immune cells to the site of infection.
  • Alternative complement pathway:  Bacterial cell wall fragments (eg, lipopolysaccharide) can directly activate complement C3, the starting point of the alternative complement pathway (
    figure 2
    ).

Activation

If natural barriers are breached, the innate immune system is activated by danger signals (alarmins) that consist of the following (

):

  • Pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs):  foreign motifs on invading microbes (eg, lipopolysaccharide, beta glucan)
  • Damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs):  self motifs released from necrotic host cells (eg, mitochondrial DNA, histones)

PAMPs and DAMPs engage pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) (eg, toll-like receptors) on innate immune cells (eg, neutrophils, macrophages).  In addition to leukocytes, PRRs are also expressed by endothelial cells and platelets, which also participate in the acute inflammatory response.

Effector response

Once activated, the innate immune system eliminates pathogens (and infected cells) through granulophagocytic killing and the alternative complement cascade.

  • Granulocytic killing:
    • Neutrophils destroy pathogens by releasing free radicals (eg, superoxide, hydrogen peroxide; known as "respiratory burst"), toxins (eg, lysozyme, proteases), and extracellular traps (eg, DNA and histones) (
      figure 3
      ).
    • NK cells are granule-containing lymphocytes that destroy infected cells displaying stress ligands (eg, heat shock proteins).  Many viruses evade adaptive immunity by downregulating major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I, which presents intracellular antigens; NK cells counter this by targeting cells with reduced MHC I expression ("missing self").  They kill via lytic molecules (eg, perforin, granzyme) and receptor-induced apoptosis (eg, Fas ligand [FasL]).  NK cells function as the innate counterparts to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes in adaptive immunity (
      figure 4
      ).
  • Phagocytic killing:  Phagocytes include macrophages (macro = big; phage = eat) and dendritic cells.  They kill pathogens through engulfment followed by lysosomal degradation (
    figure 5
    ).  Phagocytes also serve as antigen-presenting cells (APCs) due to their ability to capture and display microbial peptides on MHC.  They move from the site of infection to the nearest lymphoid tissue (eg, Peyer patch, lymph nodes), where they encounter naive T cells to initiate the adaptive immune response.  Neutrophils also have phagocytic activity (minor function) but do not contribute to antigen presentation.
  • Alternative complement activation:  Alternative complement refers to direct activation of C3 by bacterial PAMPs (eg, lipopolysaccharide).  (In contrast, the classical complement pathway relies on IgM and IgG antibody binding to antigens from pathogens or autoantigens to initiate the complement cascade.)  Activation results in assembly of the membrane attack complex (MAC), consisting of complements C5b to C9.  MAC kills bacteria by introducing pores in the cell wall (
    figure 6
    ).  Complement activation amplifies the immune response, increasing endothelial permeability and leukocyte recruitment.  In addition, C3b coats bacteria (ie, opsonization), marking them for phagocytic killing.

Adaptive immunity:  cell-mediated

Cell-mediated immunity is driven by T cells.

T-cell development

T cells are produced by the bone marrow and relocate to the thymus in infancy and early childhood.  In the thymus, they are taught to differentiate between self and nonself antigens ("T-cell education").  To accomplish this, all T cells express a T-cell receptor (TCR), consisting of antigen-recognizing and MHC-binding alpha and beta chains.  V(D)J recombination, mediated by endonucleases (eg, RAG1 and RAG2), rearranges these chains to produce a massive repertoire of TCRs with different affinities:

  • Positive selection ensures that TCRs bind strongly enough to self MHC to interact effectively with APCs.
  • Negative selection ensures that TCRs do not bind too strongly to MHC, deleting clones that are highly self-reactive to avoid autoimmunity.  In adulthood, negative selection continues in secondary lymphoid organs (eg, spleen, lymph nodes, mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue [MALT]).

T-cell activation

When APCs move from the site of infection to the nearest lymphoid tissue (eg, lymph nodes), they encounter naive T cells.  Two signals are required for activation:

  • Signal 1 (TCR-MHC):  TCRs must recognize an antigen-MHC complex (
    figure 7
    ) when APCs move from the site of infection to the nearest lymphoid organ.
    • CD8+ (cytotoxic) T cells synapse with MHC I, which displays intracellular antigens, such as viral proteins (
      figure 8
      ).  MHC I is found on all nucleated cells (including APCs).
    • CD4+ (helper) T cells synapse with MHC II, which displays extracellular antigens, such as bacterial cell wall polysaccharides (
      figure 9
      ).  MHC II is exclusively found on APCs.
  • APCs can also cross-present phagocytosed extracellular antigens on their MHC I, enhancing the cytotoxic T-cell response to nonviral infections.
  • Signal 2 (costimulation):  Signal 1 by itself is not enough.  Costimulation is needed through binding of CD80/86 (on APCs) to CD28 (on naive T cells) respectively.  This second check prevents inappropriate T-cell activation from random encounters with low levels of antigen.  Without signal 2, T cells become anergic even in the presence of TCR-MHC interaction (
    figure 10
    ).

Superantigens (eg, staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome) bypass normal antigen presentation and costimulation by indiscriminately linking TCRs to MHC, leading to widespread T-cell activation (eg, up to 25% of all T cells at once) and cytokine storm (

figure 11
).

Effector function

Once activated, cell-mediated immunity is divided between cytotoxic (CD8+) and helper (CD4+) T cell responses:

  • Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) induce apoptosis of infected cells by releasing lytic enzymes (eg, perforin, granzyme) and FasL-induced apoptosis.  (CTLs are the adaptive immune counterpart to NK cells in the innate immune system.)
  • Helper T cells (Th) assist many other immune cells by secreting interleukins and cytokines.
    • IFN-Î³ further activates macrophages, stimulating phagocytosis and granuloma formation
    • IL-2 broadly stimulates T, B, and NK cells
    • IFN-Î³ and IL-21 activate B cells and promote class switching to IgG
    • IL-5 and TGFêžµ activate B cells and promote class switching to IgA
    • IL-4 and IL-13 (Th2 skew) activate B cells and promote class switching to IgE

T-cell memory

Approximately 10% of activated T cells become memory T cells (both CD4+ and CD8+).  They patrol the circulation and mucosal surfaces and reside within lymphoid tissue.  They are very long-lived (eg, decades), maintained by survival cytokines (eg, IL-7, IL-15).  Memory T cells have a lower threshold for activation (eg, upregulated costimulatory CD28) and can expand quickly on reexposure to their target antigen.

Adaptive immunity:  antibody-mediated (humoral)

Humoral immunity is driven by B cells and antibodies.  ("Humor" refers to body fluid, reflecting the ability to passively transfer immunity through plasma containing antibodies.)

B-cell development

The development of B cells occurs in the fetal bone marrow, and most of their initial diversity is established prior to birth.  Similar to the process T cells undergo in the thymus, immature marrow B cells undergo a process of positive and negative selection to differentiate between self and nonself antigens.  All B cells express a B-cell receptor (BCR) that has a variable antigen-binding (Fab) region.  V(D)J recombination, mediated by endonucleases (eg, RAG1 and RAG2), rearranges this region to produce a massive repertoire of BCRs with different affinities:

  • Positive selection ensures only pre-B cells with functional BCRs survive.
  • Negative selection eliminates B cells that react strongly to self BCRs; this promotes self-tolerance.

Self-tolerant B cells then migrate to secondary lymphoid organs, where they await activation by helper T cells when the adaptive immune response is triggered.

B-cell activation

B-cell activation is T-cell dependent.  Similar to cell-mediated immunity, 2 signals are required for activation.  These interactions take place within the follicular zone of the secondary lymphoid tissue.

  • Signal 1 (BCR antigen):  Naive B cells capture soluble antigens via their BCRs (surface-bound IgM or IgD).  The antigen is endocytosed, processed, and redisplayed on B cell MHC II.  The B cell now effectively becomes APC to nearby CD4+ T helper cells.
  • Signal 2 (T cell help and costimulation):  CD4+ T helper TCRs synapse with the B cell antigen-MHC complexes.  Costimulation is provided by CD40 on the B cell and CD40L on the helper T cell.

After receiving signals 1 and 2, the activated B cell moves into the germinal center of the lymph node, where it undergoes class switching followed by somatic hypermutation.

  • Class switching:  Unstimulated B cells express surface IgM and IgD by default.  After activation, the immunoglobulin heavy chain constant region undergoes recombination to swap out its constant region (
    figure 12
    ), enabling switching to IgG, IgE, or IgA depending on the prevailing interleukin (eg, IL-4 for IgE).
  • Somatic hypermutation:  The immunoglobulin heavy chain variable region undergoes point mutagenes, which fine tunes the binding region to produce strong and specific affinity to its epitope.  This process is also called affinity maturation.

After these final steps, approximately 95% of activated B cells differentiate into plasma cells.  The transition is marked by losing CD19 and CD20 and acquiring CD138.  Plasma cells have an expanded endoplasmic reticulum and abundant ribosomes to maximize protein (antibody) synthesis.  Their nuclei are eccentrically positioned (resembling a fried egg) to make room for this machinery.  Plasma cells produce antibodies throughout the course of infection, often surviving for days to weeks.

Immunoglobulins

Immunoglobulins (eg, antibodies) are composed of a pair of heavy and light chains, giving them a Y-shaped form (

figure 13
).  Each light chain has 1 variable region and 1 constant region; each heavy chain has 1 variable region and 3 or 4 constant regions (CH1-4) depending on the immunoglobulin type.

Immunoglobulins are generally further divided into 2 functional pieces as follows:

  • The Fab fragment (the 2 prongs of the Y) comprises the entire light chain as well as the variable and the first constant region (CH1) of the heavy chain.  This portion of the immunoglobulin uses the variable regions of the light and heavy chain to bind specific antigenic epitopes.
  • The Fc fragment (the stalk of the Y) comprises the remaining constant regions (eg, CH2-4) of the heavy chain.  The Fc fragment exerts the effector functions of the molecule, which may include activating the classical complement cascade or binding the Fc receptor on phagocytic cells.

There are 5 classes (isotypes) of immunoglobulins, determined by the heavy chain (

figure 14
):

  • IgD exists as a surface-bound monomer (as part of BCR).
  • IgM exists as a surface-bound monomer (as part of BCR) and a soluble pentamer (in circulation).  IgM is the first antibody class produced during the initial adaptive response to a new antigen (ie, no class switching yet).  Appearance of soluble IgM indicates recent or acute infection.
  • IgG exists as a soluble monomer formed via class switching from IgM.  "Seroconversion" from IgM to IgG typically indicates chronic infection, previously cleared infection (ie, established immunity), or a vaccination response.  IgG is the most abundant immunoglobulin and is able to cross the placenta to confer passive immunity.
  • IgA exists as a soluble dimer formed via class switching from IgM.  IgA is primarily found in mucosal secretions (eg, breast milk, saliva, respiratory tract) and is highly effective at neutralization (covering pathogens to prevent them from attaching to epithelial surfaces).
  • IgE is initially secreted (by B and plasma cells) and then covalently attaches to FcÎµRI receptors on the surface of mast cells and basophils.  IgE provides immunity against parasites (eg, helminths) but also causes allergic hypersensitivity.  Soluble IgE, the unbound monomer, has no immunologic activity by itself but can be used as a marker of allergic sensitization.

Within each class, kappa (Îº) and lambda (Î») variants are determined by the light chain.  A normal Îº/Î» ratio is 2:1; abnormal ratios can potentially indicate a monoclonal expansion of B cells (eg, multiple myeloma).

Effector function

Antibodies coat pathogens and combat infection in 4 ways:

  • Opsonization tags pathogens for phagocytosis.  The Fab region of the antibody binds to the antigen, and the Fc region of the antibody is recognized by dedicated receptors on phagocytes.  This is the principal mechanism of microbial clearance.
  • Neutralization prevents pathogen binding to host cells.  Neutralizing antibodies typically target the microbe's attachment or docking proteins (eg, influenza's hemagglutinin).  Measuring neutralizing titer is the gold standard for evaluating vaccine effectiveness in vitro.
  • Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity marks pathogens for direct cytolytic killing by NK cells, which recognize FcÎ³ (IgG).
  • Classical complement pathway coats pathogens (IgM and IgG only) to activate C1q at the start of the classical complement pathway, ultimately leading to formation of the membrane attack complex MAC.  Therefore, IgM and IgG are said to be able to "fix complement."

B-cell memory

Approximately 95% of activated B cells become plasma cells, and the remaining 5% become memory B cells.  These memory cells reside in the germinal center of secondary lymphoid tissue and can circulate through the lymphatics, bloodstream, and peripheral sites.  The memory pool is maintained by survival interleukins (eg, IL-15, IL-21) and low levels of ongoing costimulation (eg, CD40-CD40L).  They have a low threshold for activation and can quickly reexpand and differentiate into plasma cells.

Primary immunodeficiencies

Primary immunodeficiency (PID) refers to a genetic defect causing abnormal susceptibility to infections.  PIDs are typically classified as follows:

  • Innate:  characterized by defective granulocytes, phagocytes, or terminal complement, with normal T cells, B cells, and immunoglobulins
  • T cell (cellular):  characterized by defective T cells, often with secondary B-cell deficiency (eg, immunoglobulin deficiency) due to lack of T helper activity
  • B cell (humoral):  characterized by defective B cells leading to immunoglobulin deficiency
  • T cell and B cell (combined):  characterized by defective T cells, B cells, and immunoglobulins

Most PIDs manifest in early childhood.  Minor B cell defects, such as mild forms of common variable immunodeficiency, may only be recognized in middle age (eg, an adult with recurrent pneumonia and bronchiectasis).

Innate

Primary innate immunodeficiencies involve genetic defects of granulocytes, phagocytes, or terminal complement.

  • Chronic granulomatous disease (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ) is an X-linked defect of NADPH oxidase, resulting in a weak respiratory burst and incomplete phagolysosomal killing.  Its primary feature is recurrent infections from catalase-positive organisms (eg, Staphylococcus aureus, Aspergillus spp) due to their ability to neutralize the insufficient levels of hydrogen peroxide produced by dysfunctional neutrophils.  Unresolved foci of infection lead to persistent inflammation and granuloma formation in multiple organs.
  • Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ) is an autosomal recessive defect in integrins (eg, CD18), resulting in impaired endothelial docking and migration to sites of infection.  It causes recurrent infections (eg, cellulitis), characteristic noninflammatory ("cold") abscesses lacking pus (despite high circulating leukocytes), poor wound healing, and delayed umbilical cord separation.
  • Chediak-Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive defect in lysosomal trafficking machinery, resulting in recurrent bacterial infections (eg, defective phagocytic killing), oculocutaneous albinism (eg, retained melanin and retinal pigment granules), and neurodegeneration (eg, lysosomal buildup).  Peripheral blood shows giant granules within leukocytes (
    figure 15
    ).
  • Terminal complement deficiency is an autosomal recessive defect in components of the membrane attach complex (C5b, C6, C7, C8, or C9).  An acquired deficiency can be induced by eculizumab therapy (eg, for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria) (
    figure 16
    ).  It results in susceptibility to invasive bacterial infections, particularly by Neisseria meningitidis and N gonorrhoeae.

The signature of innate immunodeficiency is recurrent infections despite normal indices of adaptive immunity, as demonstrated by:

  • Normal T, B, and NK cell counts (ie, "TBNK" flow cytometry panel)
  • Normal serum immunoglobulin (IgM, IgG, IgA, IgE) levels
  • Normal vaccine response (ie, >4-fold increase in specific IgG after immunization)

Cellular (T cell)

Primary cellular immunodeficiencies involve genetic defects in T-cell development or function.  Patients are prone to opportunistic infections from viruses (eg, herpes simplex virus), fungi (eg, Candida), protozoa (eg, Giardia), and atypical intracellular bacteria (eg, Pneumocystis, Mycobacterium tuberculosis).

  • DiGeorge syndrome (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: 22q112 deletion syndromes 22qDS
    ) is an autosomal dominant disorder due to microdeletion of 22q11.2.  Failed pharyngeal pouch development leads to thymic agenesis, hypocalcemia (eg, primary hypoparathyroidism), cardiac defects, and craniofacial anomalies.  TBNK flow cytometry shows markedly reduced or absent T cells but relatively preserved B and NK cell counts.  Secondary humoral immunodeficiency (eg, hypogammaglobulinemia) is common because B-cell activation relies on T-cell support.
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis (CMC) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
    ) is a group of disorders (various inheritance patterns) related to defective Th17 function, a subset of CD4+ helper T cells concentrated in the skin and mucosae necessary for epithelial repair and fungal defense.  Patients have recurrent, severe candidal infections such as thrush, esophagitis, and diffuse rashes.  Job (hyper-IgE) syndrome (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
    ), caused by defective STAT3 (critical transcription factor for Th17 differentiation), is a specific form of CMC associated with a compensatory but ineffective increase in Th2 skewing (eg, elevated IgE).

Humoral (B cell)

Primary humoral immunodeficiencies involve genetic defects in B-cell development and antibody production (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 7
).  Patients are prone to develop bronchiectasis due to recurrent sinopulmonary infections from encapsulated extracellular bacteria (eg, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae).  These bacteria are mainly cleared through antibody-dependent mechanisms (eg, opsonization).  Chronic diarrhea due to lack of gut mucosal IgA defense is also common.

  • X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 8
    ) is the most severe humoral immunodeficiency.  It is caused by defective Bruton tyrosine kinase, leading to arrested B-cell development at an early stage.  Patients exhibit absent B cells (but normal T and NK cell counts), low to absent levels of all immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, IgM), and underdeveloped lymphoid tissue (eg, lack of tonsils and lymph nodes).
  • Hyper-IgM syndrome is an X-linked defect due to lack of CD40 ligand, which is required for B-cell costimulation and class switching.  Blocked class switching leads to accumulation of B cells capable of expressing only IgM.  Patients exhibit normal B cell counts, elevated IgM but absent levels of other classes (IgG, IgE, IgA), and compensatory lymphoid hyperplasia.
  • Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 9
    ) is a large group of defects caused by impaired differentiation of B cells into plasma cells.  Most mutations are sporadic (not inherited).  Patients exhibit normal B cell counts and nonselective hypogammaglobulinemia (roughly equal reduction in all classes).  Acquired CVID occurs in the setting of lymphoproliferative disorders (eg, chronic lymphocytic leukemia) and autoimmune conditions (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus).
  • Selective IgA deficiency (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 10
    ) is the most common primary immunodeficiency.  Most cases are inherited, but the exact genetic loci are poorly defined.  Although it is mainly asymptomatic, severe deficiency can manifest with recurrent sinusitis, pneumonia, and gastroenteritis.  It is also associated with anaphylactic transfusion reactions when donor IgA (eg, present in plasma) is recognized as foreign by recipient IgE.  Patients have normal B cell counts and normal levels of every other immunoglobulin classes.
  • IgG subclass deficiency is a subclass deficiency that involves specific reductions in one or more IgG isoforms (eg, IgG1, IgG2, IgG3, or IgG4) due to subtle defects in class switching.  It can be challenging to detect because patients exhibit a normal B cell count and normal total IgG and other immunoglobulins.  However, pneumococcal (encapsulated) vaccine response is poor (<2-fold increase in titer).

Combined (T cell and B cell)

Combined primary immunodeficiencies involve profound defects in T and B cell development.  They manifest with features of both cellular and humoral immunodeficiency (eg, myriad opportunistic infections due to viruses, fungi, bacteria, and protozoa).

  • Severe combined immunodeficiency (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 11
    ) is characterized by defects in T-cell development involving loss of RAG1 or RAG2 (necessary for V(D)J recombination), adenosine deaminase (necessary for purine balance in lymphocytes), or IL-2RG (gamma chain shared by several cytokine receptors including IL-2, IL-4, and others).  Patients exhibit low or absent T cells, B cells, and immunoglobulins.
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 12
    ) is a X-linked defect of actin cytoskeleton organization in lymphocytes and platelets.  Although T and B cell counts are normal, they are unable to reshape their membranes to interact effectively with APCs.  Megakaryocytes are unable to pinch off their cytoplasm to generate platelets.  The syndrome involves the triad of recurrent sinopulmonary infections, thrombocytopenia, and eczema.  The eczema is due to compensatory but ineffective increase in Th2 skewing.
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 13
    ) is an autosomal recessive defect in the ATM gene, a DNA double strand break repair protein necessary for proper cell cycle progression.  Accumulation of unrepaired genetic damage leads to lymphocyte apoptosis (eg, low T and B cell counts), cerebellar degeneration (eg, ataxia), and a variety of malignancies (especially leukemias and lymphomas).

Summary

The immune system is divided into innate and adaptive branches (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 14
).

Innate immunity provides a rapid, nonspecific response to pathogens through natural barriers (eg, skin), granulocytic killing (eg, neutrophils, natural killer cells), phagocytosis (eg, macrophages), and alternative complement.

Adaptive immunity provides a memory-based response to nonnative patterns and is further divided into cell-mediated immunity (T cells) and antibody-mediated (humoral) immunity (B cells and antibodies).

  • Cell-mediated immunity is primarily responsible for controlling viruses (eg, Epstein-Barr virus), fungi (eg, Candida), and atypical intracellular bacteria (eg, Mycobacterium tuberculosis).
  • Humoral immunity is more effective against extracellular encapsulated bacteria (eg, Streptococcus pneumoniae).

Primary immunodeficiencies are genetic defects that affect innate immunity (eg, chronic granulomatous disease), T cells (eg, DiGeorge syndrome), B cells (eg, X-linked agammaglobulinemia), or combined T cells and B cells (eg, severe combined immunodeficiency).
